## Meeting Notes

### Deal Review Process & Lead Generation Strategy

- Jon and Kritika reviewed proactive lead generation approach using existing accounts
- Filter criteria for high-intent prospects:
  - 250-999 employee companies
  - 70%+ account TLU last month
  - Multiple free accounts with paid plans (Teams/Pro)
- Example: Nano Nets with 166 free accounts, 2 Teams accounts signals strong expansion opportunity
  - Strategic priorities: market expansion, enterprise sales, document processing
  - Team connections available through Jon Boyer
- Need to leverage team navigator connections for introductions
- Padmapriya to focus on identifying signals for account expansion flags

### Horizon Ventures Pioneering Deal Strategy

- Originally targeting Friday 1/23 close, now pushed to early February
- Technical win achieved - met all feature requirements including bring-your-own-model
- Key question: support partnership model beyond basic platform purchase
- CIO wants depth on go-forward support before economic approval
- Francis (TAM) joining Friday call to discuss ongoing partnership
- Legal/procurement won’t start until economic “yes” confirmed

#### Pricing & Urgency Strategy

- Current proposal: $79k (base platform + enhanced support)
- Recommended approach: offer $69k for January signature
  - Position as eating $10k enhanced support cost
  - Create month-end urgency
  - Next month reverts to $79k standard pricing
- ROI case: $247k savings identified
- Strategy to accelerate: get Sarah connected to systems this week to show immediate progress

#### Service Delivery Framework

- Condense timeline to Q1-Q2 foundation building
- Position Q3-Q4 as org rollout discussion for later
- Emphasize immediate ROI over year-long roadmap
- Use workshops as momentum driver, not urgency creator

### SVA Deal Revival Needed

- Previous contacts (principal director, architect) both left company
- Working with business analyst to introduce new principal running AI program
- Close date needs updating from January 31st to February/March
- Recommendation: Michael to reach out to Brian (president) to assess priority level
- Need signal on whether deal should remain in pipeline

### AITP & Boot Camp Positioning

- Ari’s Gig Stream: CTO interested but locked in 2-year FlowBuilder contract ($38-45k/year)
- Challenge: Phil pre-committed boot camps without enterprise commitment
- New approach: gate boot camps to enterprise platform purchases
- For existing vendor contracts: position AutomateFlow as complementary for non-dev users
- Sequencing: executive boot camp → enterprise purchase → team training

### Economic Buyer Identification

- Warning: CPOs/People Ops typically not economic buyers for IT infrastructure
- Actual decision authority usually sits with CIO office
- Important for deals $250k+ where procurement involvement increases
- Need to identify true budget holders early in process

### Action Items

- Jon: Send MRR spend account list with updated filters
- Alex: Update Horizon Ventures proposal with $69k January offer, connect Sarah to systems this week
- Charles: Get intro to new SVA principal, update close date forecasting
- Ari: Separate conversation with Gig Stream contact (without Phil), focus on complementary positioning

# Horizon Ventures Invoice Implentation Working Session 2

## Meeting Details

**Meeting ID:** dc12cc98-1f30-4623-9695-2a5fc1a83d0d

**Date & Time:** Thursday, January 22, 2026 at 2:00 PM UTC

**Calendar Event ID:** 3ee7p13igv6gqils4t591tmror

**Calendar Event Title:** Horizon Ventures Invoice Implentation Working Session 2

**Organizer:** Alex Obleton (user@user)

### Attendees

- **Jordan** (user@user)
- **Ahao** (user@user)
- **Alex Obleton** (user@user)

## Meeting Notes

### Project Context & Next Steps

- Building invoice implementation working session 2 with AutomateFlow/Horizon Ventures Pioneering
- Ahao managing evaluation between AutomateFlow and Workado for automation platform
- Robert (decision maker) wants proper evaluation after team rushed into Workado contract
- Workado offering year 1 development for free but Ahao unimpressed with their support quality
- Jordan (contractor) already started building software licensing agent in Workado without Ahao’s knowledge
  - Creating political complications and resource waste
  - Ahao wants structured approach to avoid similar issues

### Evaluation Criteria & Approach

- Focus areas for 3-month pilot comparison:
  1. Usability for citizen development
    - Multiple IT team members building their own automations
    - Executive productivity sessions (5-10 C-suite members)
    - Workshop format: 1-hour hands-on agent building
  2. Build capability comparison
    - AutomateFlow team builds invoice assistant
    - Ahao builds one use case with Jordan’s support
    - Compare contractor time/spend vs AutomateFlow support model
  3. Security & compliance features
    - Data residency options, retention time, data masking
    - External log streaming capabilities
    - MSA coverage requirements
- Success metrics: ease of use, multiple builds completed, citizen development readiness

### Pilot Structure & Pricing

- Proposed pilot cost: $20k for 3 months (quarter of full year amount)
- Structure: TAM hours + credit usage toward 600k annual credit cap
- Contract approach:
  - MSA with legal team (Robert comfortable moving forward)
  - Credits consumed during pilot count toward full enterprise agreement if converted
- Timeline: Results presentation to exec team by March 31st
- Ahao has AP team meeting tomorrow for detailed invoice process flow requirements

---

## Meeting Details

## Meeting Notes

### Competitive Situation

- Competitor building on Riccato platform in background while negotiating
- They have full in-house contractor dedicated to Riccato development
  - Makes direct competition difficult
- Alex feeling frustrated about lack of transparency during negotiations

### Differentiation Strategy

- Enterprise features as table stakes (security, data, bring-your-own-model)
  - Both solutions James have these capabilities
- Key differentiator: citizen development adoption across entire company
  - Getting every person up to speed and engaged
- Workshop approach could FlowBuilder significant impact
- **Number of automations built by people on the team** - potential success metric
- **Getting started** focus: connect all systems, test apps, verify permissions (Outlook, etc.)

### Secret Mission Approach

- Try to get Sarah building personal productivity automations in AutomateFlow
  - Build her confidence through hands-on experience
  - “Hey, you should go” approach once she realizes ease of use
- Focus on connection setup first to build her confidence

### Commercial Strategy

- Next couple months proceed as originally planned
- Two-month evaluation period ending with decision point
- Potential broader AI transformation pitch (100k+ project)
  - Position after pilot success rather than upfront
  - Avoid commercial discussions during evaluation
  - Different pricing justified for expanded long-term contract including training and system development
- Silver lining: some revenue expected this month

# Horizon Ventures Invoice Implentation Working Session 2

## Meeting Details

**Meeting ID:** dc12cc98-1f30-4623-9695-2a5fc1a83d0d

**Date & Time:** Thursday, January 22, 2026 at 2:00 PM UTC

**Calendar Event ID:** 3ee7p13igv6gqils4t591tmror

**Calendar Event Title:** Horizon Ventures Invoice Implentation Working Session 2

**Organizer:** Alex Obleton (user@user)

### Attendees

- **Jordan** (user@user)
- **Ahao** (user@user)
- **Alex Obleton** (user@user)

## Meeting Notes

### Project Context & Next Steps

- Building invoice implementation working session 2 with AutomateFlow/Horizon Ventures Pioneering
- Ahao managing evaluation between AutomateFlow and Workado for automation platform
- Robert (decision maker) wants proper evaluation after team rushed into Workado contract
- Workado offering year 1 development for free but Ahao unimpressed with their support quality
- Jordan (contractor) already started building software licensing agent in Workado without Ahao’s knowledge
  - Creating political complications and resource waste
  - Ahao wants structured approach to avoid similar issues

### Evaluation Criteria & Approach

- Focus areas for 3-month pilot comparison:
  1. Usability for citizen development
    - Multiple IT team members building their own automations
    - Executive productivity sessions (5-10 C-suite members)
    - Workshop format: 1-hour hands-on agent building
  2. Build capability comparison
    - AutomateFlow team builds invoice assistant
    - Ahao builds one use case with Jordan’s support
    - Compare contractor time/spend vs AutomateFlow support model
  3. Security & compliance features
    - Data residency options, retention time, data masking
    - External log streaming capabilities
    - MSA coverage requirements
- Success metrics: ease of use, multiple builds completed, citizen development readiness

### Pilot Structure & Pricing

- Proposed pilot cost: $20k for 3 months (quarter of full year amount)
- Structure: TAM hours + credit usage toward 600k annual credit cap
- Contract approach:
  - MSA with legal team (Robert comfortable moving forward)
  - Credits consumed during pilot count toward full enterprise agreement if converted
- Timeline: Results presentation to exec team by March 31st
- Ahao has AP team meeting tomorrow for detailed invoice process flow requirements

---

### Strategy Discussion: Two-Week Trial vs. Pilot

- Looking for significant customer input within next two weeks
- Team sync scheduled next Wednesday to decide final approach
- Option to connect with internal champions (Rachel Maby in HR, Sarah in RevOps - both AI engineers)
- Alternative: run sessions with department leaders within two weeks rather than extended pilot

### Risk Assessment: Agents vs. AI Steps

- Customer using terms “agents” and “agentic” without clear understanding of distinction
- Key risk: AutomateFlow doesn’t currently price agents separately
  - Could introduce cost uncertainty if they specifically need agents vs. AI by AutomateFlow steps

- Customer mentioned bring-your-own-model requirement from first call
  - AI by AutomateFlow allows connecting own LLM keys
  - Agent model control on roadmap but not current capability

### EA Use Case Opportunity

- Customer mentioned EA use case on IntegrateHub that’s expensive
- Recommended approach: clarify if “EA” means executive assistant
- Potential quick win: build EA workflow in \~15 minutes vs. expensive IntegrateHub recipe
  - Could save \~$15K compared to IntegrateHub’s per-recipe pricing model
  - IntegrateHub charges $15-20K for 5 recipes with uncapped usage
- Consider running EA-focused workshop alongside IT Leaders Workshop
- Opportunity for side-by-side comparison during two-week trial

### Competitive Positioning vs. IntegrateHub

- Medium-term strategy: prove ease of use, then migrate expensive recipes
- IntegrateHub pricing structure creates opportunities:
  - Per-recipe pricing model expensive for simple use cases
  - Uncapped usage deals don’t FlowBuilder sense for single-function teams
- Focus on cost-effective recipe migration after proving initial value
- Customer indicated IntegrateHub and AutomateFlow operate in different playing fields

### Process Improvements & Next Steps

- Start security paperwork immediately (customers James ask anyway)
- Emphasize enterprise security: models not used for training on customer materials
- Frame as truly free trial rather than paid pilot to reduce friction
- Focus on tactical execution:
  1. Draft criteria for two-week evaluation
  2. Clarify EA use case details
  3. Coordinate leader meetings
  4. Begin security documentation
- If customer requests more time after two weeks, shift to Francis conversation about putting money down

# AutomateFlow Pilot Alignment for Horizon Ventures Pioneering

## Meeting Details

**Meeting ID:** 9e0e4769-0ac6-4ae6-9df6-f505fca6379e

**Date & Time:** Friday, January 23, 2026 at 1:30 PM UTC

**Calendar Event ID:** 5ug6ogj19n25a4227ndfgv425i

**Calendar Event Title:** AutomateFlow Pilot Alignment for Horizon Ventures Pioneering

**Organizer:** Alex Obleton (user@user)

### Attendees

- **Jstarr** (user@user)
- **Jordan** (user@user)
- **Ahao** (user@user)
- **Frmichon** (user@user)
- **David Yu** (user@user)
- **Kyungho Rhee** (user@user)
- **Alex Obleton** (user@user)

## My Notes

IT or PI

Finance

Security set up piece specifically

Get legal up and running

Champions in your business who are already doing some workflows on micriosoft in those tools

Kickoff call on Monday

Do an enterprise trial, and provide that for the team, access getting connected, maybe the end of next week and we book

Bring in Brian and David can tag along when we get to the connections to the enterprise systems

Biggest questions mark is James be able to do writing and upload connections through ProcureSoft

## Meeting Notes

### Partnership Approach & Support Structure

- AutomateFlow’s proposed three-phase model for Horizon Ventures engagement:
  1. Build together phase - Jordan and Sarah work side-by-side on initial use cases
    - Target: $390k annual value from two initial automation workflows
    - Goal: Institutional knowledge transfer while accelerating delivery
  2. Enablement phase - Sarah trained, TAM handles complex builds
    - Sarah enables 80-90% of typical AutomateFlow tasks internally
    - Strategic guidance continues for complex organizational coordination
  3. Scale phase - Citizen development rollout across organization
    - People-driven priorities inform platform expansion
    - Reduced TAM dependency with ongoing strategic support

### Current Platform Context & Decision Framework

- IntegrateHub serves as established middleware at Horizon Ventures (several years)
  - Teams satisfied with existing orchestration workflows
  - Strong business-critical app-to-app connectivity
  - No immediate replacement need for current functionality
- AI agent capabilities driving AutomateFlow exploration
  - New functionality IntegrateHub also claims to offer
  - Need to evaluate best platform for enterprise AI roadmap
- Economic considerations James heavily influence final decision
- Horizon Ventures wants to stay agile in rapidly evolving orchestration market

### Pilot vs. Trial Discussion

- Horizon Ventures requirements: Must test before committing to annual contract
  - Previous software purchases didn’t deliver expected value
  - Won’t proceed without proving solution effectiveness
- AutomateFlow typically avoids pilots due to:
  - Citizen development model gets delayed during pilot phase
  - Full system connections required anyway (time investment)
  - Premium pricing typically added to pilot engagements
- Alternative approach: Two-week enterprise trial with full support
  - Jordan continues hands-on assistance
  - External TeamChat channel for ongoing support
  - Full platform access with security controls
  - Path to either full partnership or structured three-month pilot

### Evaluation Criteria & Success Metrics

- Citizen development validation requirements:
  - Sessions with IT leadership and executives
  - Demonstrate ease of agent setup and daily productivity automation
  - Assess learning curve for non-technical users
  - Test enterprise-wide platform rollout feasibility
- Complex workflow capability assessment:
  - Head-to-head comparison with IntegrateHub build experience
  - Quality of output from robust workflow automation
  - Integration capabilities with enterprise systems
- Target groups for citizen development testing:
  - IT or PI (Process Innovation) teams
  - Finance team for practical evaluation
  - Legal department as potential pilot users
  - Champions already using Microsoft workflow tools

### Invoice Automation Use Case Development

- Primary pilot project: Invoice processing automation
  - Solid ROI story foundation
  - Simplest use case from Horizon Ventures’s broader AI roadmap
- Key implementation requirements:
  - Pre-work on app connections (especially Outlook approval process)
  - Finance team meeting Monday for current state mapping
  - AutomateFlow team to join follow-up design session as observers
  - Brian (IntegrateHub expert) inclusion for head-to-head comparison
- Biggest question mark: ProcureSoft integration capabilities
  - Writing and uploading through connections
  - Enterprise system connectivity and security compliance
  - David involvement for security and connectivity decision points

### Next Steps

- Enterprise trial setup for Horizon Ventures team access
- Wednesday/Thursday check-in meeting (January 29/30)
  - Progress assessment on invoice automation build
  - Decision on trial extension vs. paid pilot vs. full partnership
- Finance team meetings:
  - Kickoff call today for goals and current state
  - Follow-up design session next week (AutomateFlow team invited)
- Include Brian and David in build process for technical evaluation
- Potential IT extended leadership team workshop (45-60 minutes)
  - Hands-on citizen development demonstration
  - Team members bring specific pain points/use cases
  - Pre-setup accounts and connector resolution

---

# AutomateFlow Trial Check-in

## Meeting Details

**Meeting ID:** bd7b431e-1a51-48d6-88e1-62affa070f9c

**Date & Time:** Thursday, January 29, 2026 at 2:00 PM UTC

**Calendar Event ID:** 1a5tdvbs5boe3f2tui2khl8jsn

**Calendar Event Title:** AutomateFlow Trial Check-in

**Organizer:** Alex Obleton (user@user)

### Attendees

- **Jordan Floyd** (user@user)
- **Ahao** (user@user)
- **David Yu** (user@user)
- **Alex Obleton** (user@user)

## My Notes

One other use case would be where it's pulling from brand folder and using some kind of google vision API to do the facial recognition.

BrandFolder as their digitial tool, put all of their event photos, and every time they upload a photo they have to manually tag every single one, batch tagging, ideally facial recognition of who's in the photo, so if someone asks for a press kit they can just have it and a bunch of quries they have to do

## Meeting Notes

### Pilot Evaluation Criteria

- Citizen development capability (primary differentiator vs IntegrateHub)
  - Executive team workshop to demonstrate ease of use
  - Measure how many people can build automations
- Build speed and complexity assessment
  - Before/after surveys on learning curve
  - Support model comparison (Jordan vs IntegrateHub)
- Security and compliance requirements
  - Table stakes - both platforms should meet standards
  - Emma needs to review legal/security details
- Platform velocity measurement
  - Hypothesis: more automations possible with AutomateFlow
  - Focus on personal productivity use cases

### Pilot Pricing and Approval

- $20-50K for 2-month pilot (1.5x prorated cost)
  - Includes Jordan’s dedicated time and support
  - Covers investment/risk mitigation
- Approval process:
  - Robert (primary decision maker) - Ahao has 1:1 tomorrow
  - Emma (legal/procurement review)
- Next steps: verbal approval → formal quote → contract execution

### Technical Progress - Invoice Processing

- Data extraction now working
  - AI extracts invoice details into structured tables
  - Separate views for summary data vs line items
  - Manual trigger currently, can automate later
- ProcureSoft API connection established
  - OAuth authentication resolved (required newline-separated scopes)
  - Successfully retrieved purchase order data
  - Access token stored securely via AutomateFlow Storage
- End-to-end workflow nearly complete
  - Email → PDF extraction → PO matching → draft invoice creation
  - James demo full process to Lisa tomorrow
  - Using GPT-4 with Horizon Ventures’s API keys for better extraction

### Additional Use Case - Brand Folder

- Digital asset management automation opportunity
  - BrandFolder stores all event photos and branding assets
  - Currently requires manual tagging for every uploaded photo
- Proposed solution using Google Vision API:
  - Batch tagging capabilities
  - Facial recognition for key personnel (CEO, executives)
  - Automated press kit generation
  - Query optimization for asset retrieval
- Alternative to custom GPT approach that wasn’t working well

### Next Steps

- Ahao: Discuss pilot approval with Robert in tomorrow’s 1:1
- Ahao: Coordinate with Emma on security/legal review
- Jordan: Send Loom video for email filtering setup
- Jordan: Complete end-to-end demo preparation for Lisa meeting
- Alex: Send evaluation criteria slides and metrics framework
- Team: Plan Brand Folder facial recognition project for 2-month pilot period

---

# AI Invoice Assistant - Follow Up Questions ## Meeting Details **Meeting ID:** f66b3570-5d16-461e-a3f2-a555-XXX-XXXX0 **Date & Time:** Friday, January 30, 2026 at 5:30 PM UTC **Calendar Event ID:** _60q30c1g60o30e1i60o4ac1g60rj8gpl88rj2c1h84s34h9g60s30c1g60o30c1g88o3gc1h88rk2gq174o48gpg64o30c1g60o30c1g60o30c1g60o32c1g60o30c1g712jaci484pk4d1i8h146dhk750jag9m88s30ha58d13gc1h68qg **Calendar Event Title:** AI Invoice Assistant - Follow Up Questions **Organizer:** Alex Obleton (user@user) ### Attendees - **Jordan Floyd** (user@user) - **Sarah Hao** (user@user) - **Mike Lee** (user@user) - **David Yu** (user@user) - **Lisa Sousa** (user@user) - **Alex Obleton** (user@user) ## Meeting Notes

Current ProcureSoft Implementation & Pain Points

  • Horizon Ventures Pioneering processes AP for 52-54 portfolio companies
  • ProcureSoft rollout completed September 2024 (4 months live)
    • Three-wave implementation across all lab companies
    • Team adapting well to system changes
  • Major volume challenge: Thermo Fisher Financial alone generates 100-150 invoices monthly
    • Individual invoices, same contract amounts
    • Currently requires manual copy/paste from previous invoices
  • Draft invoice queue management nightmare
    • System saves draft every time user backs out
    • Can’t delete drafts, must manually void
    • Queue cluttered with unusable entries (zero amounts, “none” values)
    • Prevents leadership from using queue for pending invoice visibility

AutomateFlow AI Invoice Processing Demo

  • Automated email monitoring with PDF attachment detection
    • Primary format: PDF invoices
    • Secondary: Word docs, email body text
  • AI extraction capabilities demonstrated
    • Invoice header data (number, supplier, dates, payment terms)
    • Line item processing with looping functionality
    • High accuracy on initial 5-invoice test set
  • Current workflow: Email → AI extraction → AutomateFlow table → ProcureSoft integration
  • Sandbox testing preferred over production environment
    • Avoids contaminating live 50+ company data
    • David Yu to coordinate sandbox access with infrastructure team

Integration Strategy & Customization

  • Invoice status optimization
    • “New” status preferred over problematic “Draft” status
    • Custom queue creation possible for automated invoices
  • PO matching approach
    • Leave unmatched unless 100% confidence
    • API calls to retrieve PO details working successfully
    • Manual matching adjustment easier than fixing incorrect matches
  • Repetitive invoice automation potential
    • Non-PO invoices (Thermo Fisher example) always route to same GL account
    • Training data approach for recurring supplier patterns
    • End-to-end automation possible for vanilla transactions
  • Email management post-processing
    • Options: flagging, folder movement, reply confirmation
    • Process folder structure already exists per mailbox

Next Steps

  • Jordan: Extensive testing using Lisa’s dummy invoice data
    • Quality check on field extraction accuracy
    • Non-invoice attachment filtering validation
  • David Yu: Coordinate sandbox environment access for ProcureSoft testing
  • Lisa: Join upcoming executive workshop (finance team session consideration)
    • Kevin inclusion recommended
  • Draft cleanup automation exploration
    • Target invoices with “none” values and zero amounts
    • 30-day inactivity threshold consideration
  • Rossum comparison meeting scheduled (couple weeks)

Chat with meeting transcript: https://example.com/... AI.ai/t/5b21a5ff-6b36-4df2-bea1-19dae1692711

dealProperties.stage: Paid Pilot Negotiation → $20K/2 months, Sarah presenting to Robert today, quote ready
dealProperties.amount: $80K full year (pilot: $20K for 2 months with opt-out)
dealProperties.closeDate: End of March - Amy going back to COO and functional leadership team then

activityLog.description: **Awaiting Robert approval.** Sarah presenting $20K pilot in her 1:1 with Robert today. Quote ready from deal desk - James send DocuSign immediately on verbal yes. **Lisa demo completed - strong reception.** Key outcomes: (1) Lisa (AP lead, 8 yrs at Horizon Ventures, oversees 52-54 portfolio companies) now engaged and impressed - "completely eye-opening." (2) Major pain point validated: Thermo Fisher Financial = 100-150 invoices/month, same contract amounts, currently manual copy/paste. Non-PO invoices always go to same GL - prime candidate for end-to-end automation. (3) Technical decisions: Use "New" status (not Draft - Draft queue is a nightmare), leave PO matching unmatched unless 100% confident, test in ProcureSoft sandbox (David to coordinate access). (4) New automation opportunity: Draft cleanup bot - clear drafts with "none" values after 30 days (Alex idea, Lisa loved it). (5) Lisa + Kevin want to join Feb 18 workshop. (6) Rossum comparison meeting in a couple weeks - but Lisa said AutomateFlow "seems simpler and gives more control."

**Trial check-in - pivoting to paid pilot.** Key outcomes: (1) **Evaluation criteria locked:** Citizen dev usability (40%), central IT build capability (40%), security/compliance (table stakes), platform velocity. Sarah James fill out eval, Robert decides based on her confidence. (2) **Timeline confirmed: End of March.** Sarah going back to COO + functional leadership then - no Feb close possible. (3) **Pilot pricing anchored at $20K for 2 months** (1.5x prorated) - includes Jordan's dedicated time. KR aligned on this approach. (4) **Technical win: ProcureSoft API now working.** OAuth resolved (needed newline-separated scopes), successfully retrieving PO data, invoice workflow nearly end-to-end. (5) **New use case: BrandFolder facial recognition** - batch photo tagging with Google Vision API. Good 2-month pilot project. (6) **Next steps:** Sarah pitches Robert in 1:1 tomorrow, Emma reviews security/legal, Jordan demos full flow to Lisa tomorrow. If Robert verbal yes → formal quote → contract execution.

**Working session with Sarah, David, Mike (IntegrateHub SME).** Key progress: (1) Crawl/walk/run approach agreed for invoice automation - start with recurring invoices, add human-in-loop, then automate high-confidence matches. (2) AutomateFlow Form + Table set up for PDF testing - bypasses Outlook blocker. (3) Sarah has ProcureSoft admin access, Jordan sent API endpoint requirements (invoices, POs, images). (4) 15 users added to trial including David (admin) and Mike. (5) Mike met Jordan for first time - has IntegrateHub experience, used AutomateFlow ~2 years ago. **Blockers:** Outlook OAuth still no timeline, ProcureSoft API not yet connected. **Other opportunities:** Sarah experimenting with Brandfolder MCP + facial recognition (Google Vision API), asked about MCP pricing (Jordan to follow up). **Workshop:** Rachel Mabie confirmed for Feb 18. Need to get exec Outlook accounts approved before workshop. **Action:** Ask Sarah to amend Outlook request to include leadership team.
(Evening)**: **Security email + memo sent to Emma.** Short email with links + detailed memo uploaded to Google Doc. Offered call if needed. Next: follow up if no response.

(Evening)**: **Workshop planning started.** Feb 18 workshop needs prep: (1) All connections set up beforehand (Outlook OAuth, ProcureSoft), (2) Consider Rachel Mabie for "build your own agent" format, (3) Get attendee pain points in advance. Jordan + Sarah to work Monday on connections and trial user list.

(Evening)**: **Sarah responded with key details:** **IT Workshop: Feb 18 at 9:30am ET** - Robert approved, Sarah adding us to agenda **EA = Enterprise Applications** (David's team), not Executive Assistants - kills the quick win angle **ProcureSoft**: Sarah requesting admin access. Question on whether constraints are admin setup or API - she thought API but checking **Outlook OAuth**: Not approved by security yet, Sarah pinged and following up **Security/Legal**: Emma Starr (InfoSec) + Legal handles contracts. "Send package" approach works **Trial users**: Sarah James compile list, should include others beyond just her **Finance design session**: Team said review flowchart together once built **Created security brief for Emma** - SOC 2, GDPR, BYOM, enterprise controls, links to Trust Center/Enterprise Agreement. Output: `/outputs/security-brief-Emma.docx`

(Late PM)**: KR sent follow-up email to Robert, David, Sarah, Emma confirming trial structure. Outlined: (1) Two-week enterprise trial with full support from Jordan, (2) Invoice automation build continues with Sarah + Jordan, (3) IT Leadership Workshop for hands-on citizen dev testing, (4) Jan 29 check-in to assess progress and decide next steps. Framed as "define value together" and "lower your team's risk with a paid pilot." **Sarah and David accepted the Jan 29 meeting.** I'm following up with Sarah on tactical details.

(PM)**: KR debrief. Feedback: Should have asked "paid vs non-paid pilot" earlier to shortcut discussion. Risk flagged: Customer using "agents/agentic" without understanding - we don't price agents. Opportunity: EA use case on IntegrateHub may be expensive recipe we can replace quickly. Action items: Start security paperwork, clarify EA use case, prepare for Jan 29 with clear "if they want more time, they put money down" positioning. Different views on call approach - KR thinks trial is cleaner than pilot, I'm concerned Robert James just ask for more time regardless.

Alignment call with Robert, David, Sarah, Emma. Robert and Emma had 9am conflict, left after 30 min. **Key outcome: Pivoted from 3-month paid pilot to 2-week enterprise trial.** Robert firm: "Won't pay before we prove ourselves." KR pushed back on pilot approach - citizen development gets delayed, full connections still needed anyway. Landed on: (1) Enterprise trial with Jordan support continuing, (2) Thursday Jan 29 check-in, (3) Sarah/Jordan continue invoice automation build, (4) IT leadership workshop in next couple weeks, (5) Brian + David join technical builds for comparison. **$80K confirmed in range if we prove value.** Evaluation criteria rubric not validated. David was candid: "IntegrateHub is known, we're giving AutomateFlow a fair shot." Biggest technical question mark: ProcureSoft integration.

(PM)**: KR strategy sync. Key shift: Don't lead with pilot pricing tomorrow. Start with full $80K to test budget reality before discussing pilot structure. No pilot price prepared - let requirements from the call guide what we quote. If Sarah confirms Jordan's assessment (we can build, just need time), push back on pilot necessity entirely. Acceptable for deal to slip - clarity on requirements and budget more important than rushing a pilot price. KR James join call and voice over pilot positioning if needed. Talk track: "At $80K we don't typically pilot - those are for $250K deals." Prep Sarah that KR James stress-test technical feasibility with her.

(AM)**: Major pivot - deal shifted from full-year negotiation to 3-month competitive pilot vs IntegrateHub. Sarah call revealed: (1) IntegrateHub contractor already started building license governance without Sarah/Robert knowing - created internal friction, (2) Robert not tied to sunk cost, wants right long-term decision, (3) IntegrateHub support model is weak - contractor builds, they just advise, (4) Sarah James build hands-on with AutomateFlow Jordan (active) vs just observe IntegrateHub (passive). Pilot structure: License governance head-to-head + Invoice processing AutomateFlow-only + Executive workshop. Proposed $20K for 3 months, credits count toward full year if converted. March 31 deadline for exec presentation. Robert call tomorrow to align on eval criteria. **Key risk**: IntegrateHub contractor has head start. **Key opportunity**: Sarah is frustrated with IntegrateHub situation and actively championing structured eval.

Redesigned implementation timeline deck (v2 - 5 slides). New pricing play: $69K January offer with $10K support cost struck through. Simplified to Foundation/Scale/Evolve three-phase model. Removed detailed Q1-Q4 slides to avoid "let's pilot" objection. Key slides: Investment Summary ($79K standard), January Offer ($69K with strikethrough), Partnership Model (3 pillars), The Ask (questions for Robert and David). Files: `outputs/implementation-timeline.pptx`, `outputs/implementation-timeline.md`. **[Note: Deal dynamics changed Jan 22 - now in pilot mode]**

(PM)**: Built implementation timeline presentation (8 slides) for Jan 24 conversation. Framing: "Partnership, not dependency." Shows 12-month journey from building MVPs together to 100+ users with strategic partnership. Key additions: Partnership Overview slide (three pillars), Investment Summary slide ($69K + $10K = $79K, 600K tasks). BUILD lane now shows TAMs building alongside team throughout, not stepping back. Addresses Robert's "ease of use" concern and Sarah's "don't want to be dependent" concern. Files: `outputs/implementation-timeline.pptx`, `outputs/implementation-timeline.md`.

(AM)**: Leadership demo with Robert, David, Sarah. Emma couldn't join but sent questions - documented responses in MAP. Demo went well. Jordan walked through both use cases. Deep dive on BYOM - key differentiator. Robert engaged on ease of use, mentioned he tried AutomateFlow and gave up. Copilot demo helped. Got buy-in from Robert and David. Robert: "We want to be aggressive. We want to sign, but we need to FlowBuilder sure we take the time that is needed." Timeline pushed from Jan 23 → Jan 30. Scheduling Jan 24 follow-up for pricing and services model discussion. **Next**: Prep services model detail and pricing walkthrough for Jan 24. Consider executive workshop offer.
Quote delivered. TAM introduction with Francis. $80K enterprise deal.
Technical validation with Jordan and Sarah. Confirmed both use cases are viable.
Initial discovery. Identified license governance and invoice processing as priority use cases.

doc_horizon-ventures_pricing-walkthrough.content:
# Horizon Ventures Pioneering - Pricing Structure Walkthrough

*For Jan 24 follow-up conversation with Robert, David, Sarah*

---

## How to Present This

Robert said: "We need to FlowBuilder sure we have a price that is reasonable for us."

Don't lead with the number. Lead with the value breakdown, then show the math.

---

## The Investment Breakdown

### 1. Platform License: [$ TBD]

*What this covers:*
• Enterprise-grade AutomateFlow platform access
• Unlimited users (citizen development enabled)
• BYOM capability - connect your own LLM keys (OpenAI, Anthropic, Bedrock)
• App governance - control which apps users can connect
• SSO/SAML integration
• SOC 2 Type II compliance
• Priority support SLA

*Comparable to:* This is not a per-seat model. It's a platform investment.

---

### 2. TAM Support (12 hrs/mo): [$ TBD]

*Standard enterprise = 6 hours/month*
*Your package = 12 hours/month (2x standard)*

*Why we doubled it:*
• You're early in AI transformation journey
• Multiple stakeholders to train (not just Sarah)
• Two complex use cases to build in 90 days
• Goal is self-sufficiency by EOY - that takes investment

---

### 3. 90-Day Onboarding: [Included]

*This is NOT a line item charge.* Jordan's hands-on build time for your first two use cases is built into the package.

*What you'd pay externally for this:*
• Solutions architect at $250/hr × 40 hours = $10-20K+
• You're getting this included

---

### 4. AI Transformation Strategist: [Included]

*What you'd pay externally for this:*
• Strategic consulting engagement = $20-50K-50,000/year
• You're getting this included

---

## The Comparison Frame

| What You're Getting | Market Rate | Your Investment |
|--------------------|-------------|-----------------|
| Enterprise Platform | - | [$ TBD] |
| 12 hrs/mo TAM (144 hrs/year) | $36K (@$250/hr) | Included |
| 90-Day Onboarding (40+ hrs) | $10K+ | Included |
| AI Strategist | $20-50K | Included |
| TeamChat Channel Support | - | Included |

---

## Robert's Likely Question: "What's the discount?"

*Do not volunteer a discount unprompted.*

If asked, here are your levers (see January incentives doc):
• Term commitment (2 year vs 1 year)
• Signature timing (Jan vs Feb)
• Case study participation
• Reference customer commitment

---

## David's Likely Question: "Can we flex hours up/down?"

*Default answer:* No - hours are committed annually for resource planning.

*If pushed:* "Let me take that back to our team. If there's a specific scenario you're planning for, help me understand it so I can see what's possible."

Don't commit to flexibility you can't deliver.

---

## The ROI Bridge

Before price discussion, anchor on value:

*License Governance Use Case:*
• Est. dormant license cost: [$ - need from Sarah]
• If we recover even 20% = [$ value]

*Invoice Processing Use Case:*
• Hours saved per month: [X hours - need from Sarah]
• At $[Y]/hour = [$ value/year]

*Total recoverable value: [$X] vs. Investment of [$Y] = [X]x ROI*

If you don't have these numbers, ask Sarah before the Friday call.

---

## Handling "It's Too Expensive"

*Don't defend the price. Reframe the comparison.*

"What are you comparing it to?"
• If IntegrateHub: "You're already paying for IntegrateHub. This is additive capability for agentic AI - different use case."
• If internal build: "What would it cost to hire a fractional automation engineer? $150-200K fully loaded. This is 1/4 of that."
• If competitor: "What's included in their support model? Are they building the first use cases with you?"

---

## What You Need Before Friday

- [ ] Confirm the actual quote numbers to fill in [$TBD] fields
- [ ] Get license cost estimates from Sarah for ROI calculation
- [ ] Decide with KR what discount levers you have authority to use
- [ ] Confirm whether hour flexibility is possible (ask delivery team)

# Follow-up Email - Jan 16 Leadership Demo

*To: Robert, David, Sarah, Emma*

---

Subject: Horizon Ventures x AutomateFlow - Follow-up & Next Steps

Hi all,

Thank you Robert and David for taking the time today. I know there's a lot on your plate evaluating options, and we appreciate you giving us the opportunity to show what a partnership could look like.

*What we heard*

Based on today's conversation, these are the things that matter most as you FlowBuilder this decision:

• *Bring your own model* - Your team needs control over which LLMs touch your data and how. This is non-negotiable from a security and governance standpoint.
• *Ease of use* - If this is going to scale beyond Sarah, people who aren't technical need to be able to build and maintain workflows without constant hand-holding.
• *Services and support model* - You want clarity on what's included, what happens when you need to build use case #4, and how we help your team become self-sufficient over time.
• *Coexistence with IntegrateHub* - This needs to complement what's already working, not blow it up.

*For Emma*

I know you weren't able to join today, but Sarah shared your questions in advance. We've documented our responses in the mutual action plan linked below - specifically around data handling, model connectivity, and guardrails. Happy to schedule a separate conversation if you'd like to go deeper on any of those.

*Path forward*

We understand you want to move deliberately. Our goal isn't to rush you into a decision - it's to give you and your team what you need to feel confident moving forward.

Here's what we're proposing:

| Date | Activity |
|------|----------|
| Jan 20 | Sarah presents business case to COO |
| Jan 24 | Follow-up conversation on pricing and services model (Robert, David, Sarah) |
| Week of Jan 27 | Legal/procurement review |
| Jan 30 | Target contract signature and kickoff |

*What I'll bring to Jan 24*

• Detailed breakdown of our services model - what's included, how TAM hours work, what happens as you scale
• Pricing structure walkthrough so there are no surprises
• Training and enablement plan - the path to your team being self-sufficient

One other thought: Robert, you mentioned trying AutomateFlow on your own and finding it challenging. We often run executive workshops - a hands-on hour where you and a few colleagues build something you can actually use. If that would be helpful in building confidence before you commit, happy to set one up.

*Resources*

• Mutual Action Plan (includes Emma's Q&A): https://example.com/...
• Enterprise Agreement (for legal review): https://example.com/...
• Trust Center (for IT/security review): https://example.com/...

Let me know if the 24th works for the follow-up, or if there's a better time given your schedule next week.

Best,
Alex

Horizon Ventures Pioneering — Deal Channel Update

Jan 23, 2026 | Post-Alignment Call

TL;DR

Pivoted from 3-month paid pilot to 2-week enterprise trial. Robert confirmed $80K is in range IF we prove value. Next check-in Thursday Jan 29. Jordan continues building invoice automation with Sarah. Deal is still alive but execution matters now.

Status

Stage: Enterprise Trial (2 weeks) → Decision Jan 29

Amount: $80K (confirmed in range)

Close Target: Q2 — depends on trial outcomes

Competition: IntegrateHub (incumbent) — they see us for citizen dev, IntegrateHub for orchestration

What Happened

Robert (CIO) and Emma (CISO) had 9am conflict, only stayed 30 min

Robert held firm: "Won't pay before we prove ourselves" — burned by past software purchases

KR pivoted us from paid pilot negotiation to 2-week enterprise trial with full support

David (Dir, Enterprise Apps) was candid: "IntegrateHub is known, we're giving AutomateFlow a fair shot" — not just going through motions

Brian (IntegrateHub builder) James join technical sessions for direct comparison

$80K confirmed in range — gated on proving value, not budget objection

Key Risks

ProcureSoft integration: Biggest technical question mark. If we can't write/upload to their procurement system, use case doesn't close.

Robert's pattern: May ask for "more time" even if trial goes well. Need to define what "enough" looks like before Jan 29.

Criteria not validated: Still don't have specific success metrics agreed with Robert. Evaluation criteria rubric wasn't discussed.

Next Steps

KR: Sending update to Horizon Ventures on plan for next few weeks

Alex: Start security/legal paperwork, follow up with Sarah on logistics

Jordan: Continue invoice automation build with Sarah, join finance design session next week

Jan 29 check-in: Assess trial progress, decide: extend / paid pilot / full deal

IT Leadership Workshop: TBD timing — Sarah confirming when IT extended LT meets

Bottom Line

Deal shifted from pilot negotiation to execution mode. The next two weeks are about proving we can deliver, not talking about whether to pilot. If Jordan and Sarah nail the invoice automation and the IT workshop lands, we're in good shape. If we stumble, inertia wins and IntegrateHub keeps the account.

doc_horizon-ventures_julia-security-memo.title: Emma-security-memo
doc_horizon-ventures_julia-security-memo.content:
MEMO

To: Emma Starr, CISO

From: Alex Obleton, AutomateFlow

Date: January 23, 2026

Re: AutomateFlow Security Overview for Horizon Ventures Pioneering

Summary

AutomateFlow provides enterprise-grade security controls for workflow automation. Key certifications: SOC 2 Type II, SOC 3, GDPR, CCPA. For AI-powered workflows, we support a Bring Your Own Model (BYOM) approach where your data flows through your model instances.

Certifications & Compliance

SOC 2 Type II — Annual third-party audit (report available under NDA)

SOC 3 — Public report available

GDPR compliant — EU data protection requirements

CCPA compliant — California Consumer Privacy Act

Annual penetration testing — Third-party security assessments

Bug bounty program — Responsible disclosure process



Data Protection

Encryption: 256-bit AES at rest, TLS 1.2 in transit

Infrastructure: AWS (USA)

Data retention: Configurable retention periods for task history

No training on customer data: Workflow data is not used to train models

Subprocessor transparency: Public list with change notifications

DPA available: Standard Data Processing Agreement for enterprise



AI Workflow Security (BYOM)

For AI-powered workflows like invoice processing, AutomateFlow supports Bring Your Own Model:

Choose your LLM provider — OpenAI, Anthropic, Azure, or others via your accounts

Your API keys — Authentication under your control

Data flows through your instances — AutomateFlow orchestrates; you control the AI layer

Human-in-the-loop — Critical decision points can require human approval

Output validation — Built-in guardrails ensure outputs meet requirements



Enterprise Platform Controls

SSO/SAML — Integration with existing identity provider

SCIM provisioning — Automated user lifecycle management

Admin controls — Centralized visibility into automations, connections, and user activity

App restrictions — Limit which applications can be connected org-wide

MFA — Multi-factor authentication support



Resources

Trust Center: https://example.com/...

Security & Compliance: https://example.com/...

Enterprise Agreement: https://example.com/...



Next Steps

Available to support your review:

Schedule a security-focused call to walk through specific requirements

Provide SOC 2 Type II report under NDA

Complete any security questionnaire

Connect with our security team for technical questions



Contact: Alex Obleton, Account Executive — user@user

doc_horizon-ventures_jan23-talking-point.title: jan23-talking-points
doc_horizon-ventures_jan23-talking-point.content:
Horizon Ventures Pilot Evaluation

Talking Points & Meeting Roles - January 23, 2026

STRATEGIC CONTEXT (from KR sync)

Lead with full $79K pricing - test if budget is realistic before discussing pilot structure

No pilot price prepared - let requirements from this call guide what we quote

Surface their urgency - use Sarah's role as the proxy for their own timeline expectations

Stress-test pilot necessity - if Jordan can build it, why do we need a pilot?

Meeting Roles

Alex

Primary presenter. Drive the narrative, present partnership model, handle value proposition. Lead on slides 1-5.

Key moments: Partnership vision, urgency questions, evaluation criteria walkthrough

KYUNGHO

Executive air cover. Voice over pilot positioning if needed. Stress-test Sarah on technical feasibility. Handle pricing objections.

Key moments: If pilot pushback: "At $79K we don't typically pilot..." If Sarah confirms build is doable, push back on pilot necessity.

Jordan

Technical credibility. Answer detailed implementation questions. Confirm build capability and timeline.

Key moments: If asked about build complexity, confirm we can deliver if given time. Support the "this isn't a capability issue" narrative.



Slide 1: Title

Horizon Ventures Pioneering x AutomateFlow - Pilot Evaluation

Talking Points

Quick frame-set: "Today we're here to align on how we evaluate this partnership - not to close a deal, but to FlowBuilder sure we're measuring what matters for your Q3 citizen development goal."

Acknowledge Robert's concern about buying software too quickly - we heard that and want to address it head-on.

Lead: Alex

Slide 2: The Partnership

AutomateFlow + Horizon Ventures - 01 Build Together / 02 Enable Sarah / 03 Evolve Together

Talking Points

Walk through the three phases - this is the full-year vision, not just a pilot.

~$390K in quantified value - license governance ($305K) + invoice processing ($85K+).

End state quote: "Your team builds confidently. AutomateFlow helps you think bigger. Partnership, not dependency."

CRITICAL: PAUSE AND ASK URGENCY QUESTIONS HERE

Before moving to price, surface their urgency using Sarah's role:

"When you created Sarah's role, what did success by end of year look like?"

"Is it acceptable if no one outside IT is self-serving by Q3? Does that match your expectations?"

"What's the cost if Q3 citizen development slips to Q4 or next year?"

Framing: "We're not trying to rush you - we're trying to understand if the pilot timeline matches what you need from Sarah's team."

Lead: Alex | Support: Kyungho listens for urgency signals

Slide 3: Investment

$69K platform + $10K enhanced support = $79K total

Talking Points

Present full price confidently. This is what the partnership costs - we need to know if it's in range before discussing structure.

"We're pricing enhanced support at $10K instead of $15K because we want you thinking about the partnership, not the meter running."

Watch their reaction. If they flinch at $79K, we need to requalify budget before going further.

BUDGET CHECK QUESTION

"Before we go further - is this budget range realistic for a platform that delivers on the citizen development vision?"

If they say "we thought this was $20K" - STOP. Requalify. Don't proceed to pilot discussion.

Lead: Alex | Kyungho ready to voice over if needed



Slide 4: Where We Are

Structured Evaluation for Long-Term Success

Talking Points

"You've made clear that citizen development is the Q3 goal - getting every employee able to build their own automations."

Frame the pilot as answering ONE question: "Which platform James best enable Horizon Ventures employees to build confidently - not just IT, but everyone?"

Three-part structure: Build Together (head-to-head), Prove Velocity (additional use cases), Test Adoption (exec workshop).

KYUNGHO: Stress-test Sarah on technical feasibility

"Sarah, I want to FlowBuilder sure I understand the situation. Jordan told me the technical requirements are met - we just need more time to build. Is that your understanding too?"

If Sarah confirms: "So this isn't a question of whether we CAN deliver - it's about giving you confidence in the decision. That's what the evaluation structure is for."

Lead: Alex | Kyungho asks the technical question

Slide 5: Pilot Structure

What We're Building & How - Head-to-Head + AutomateFlow Additional

Talking Points

Head-to-head: License Governance. Key difference - Sarah builds hands-on with AutomateFlow, follows along passively with IntegrateHub contractor.

AutomateFlow additional: Invoice processing + executive workshop. We're showing velocity, not just parity.

"We're testing build experience, learning curve, support quality - the things that matter for citizen development."

Lead: Alex | Jordan available for technical detail questions

Slide 6: Proposed Criteria

Evaluation Framework - weighted criteria for decision

Talking Points

Walk through each criterion and weight. Top 3 (75%) directly address citizen development.

Criterion

Weight

Why It Matters

Citizen Development Readiness

30%

Can non-IT build independently?

Build Speed & Complexity

25%

Time to implement, debug effort

Support Model Quality

20%

Hands-on vs passive support

Security & Compliance

15%

BYOM, SSO, audit

Platform Velocity

10%

Use cases delivered

"We want to measure what matters for your Q3 rollout, not just technical checkboxes."

Ask: "Does this weighting reflect what matters most to you? What would you change?"

Lead: Alex | Get explicit sign-off on criteria



Slide 7: Pilot Timeline

Path Forward - Jan 23 through March 31

Talking Points

Today (Jan 23): Evaluation Criteria & Commercial Alignment

Jan 27-31: Pilot contract signed, MSA to legal

Feb 1: Pilot kickoff - begin license governance build

March 31: Pilot results presentation to exec team

Decision point: Confident recommendation on platform for Q3 citizen development rollout

KYUNGHO: If they push for pilot pricing

"At $79K, we don't typically do pilots - those are for $250K enterprise deals."

Options to voice over:

Quarterly payments with opt-out clause (not a "pilot")

Annual agreement with opt-out if metrics not hit

"Pilot pricing is always at a premium, not a discount. We need your requirements first."

Lead: Alex | Kyungho handles commercial objections

Closing & Next Steps

Questions to Answer Before We Leave

Is $79K in budget range? (Must answer before pilot discussion)

Are these evaluation criteria aligned with what matters to you?

What specific requirements would you need to see in a pilot?

Who needs to be involved in the MSA/contract review?

Acceptable Outcomes

Best: Full $79K deal, skip pilot

Good: Full-year agreement with opt-out clause

OK: Pilot with clear requirements - price separately after call

Acceptable: Deal slips but we have clarity on requirements and budget

doc_horizon-ventures_pilot-evaluation-cr.title: pilot-evaluation-criteria
doc_horizon-ventures_pilot-evaluation-cr.content:
Horizon Ventures Pioneering

Automation Platform Pilot Evaluation Criteria

Pilot Overview

This document outlines the evaluation criteria for the Q1 2026 automation platform pilot comparing AutomateFlow and IntegrateHub. The goal is to FlowBuilder a confident recommendation by March 31, 2026 for the platform that James best support Horizon Ventures's citizen development vision in Q3 and beyond.

Timeline

Date

Milestone

Jan 27-31

Pilot contracts signed, MSA finalized

Feb - Mar

Pilot execution: Build use cases, workshops, evaluation

March 31

Results presentation to executive team, platform decision

Pilot Structure

Head-to-Head: License Governance Workflow

Both platforms James build the license governance workflow to enable direct comparison:

AutomateFlow: Sarah builds hands-on with AutomateFlow team support

IntegrateHub: Sarah follows along with contractor build

Comparison points: Build experience, time to completion, ease of learning

Additional Use Cases (AutomateFlow)

To demonstrate platform velocity and breadth:

Invoice Processing: AI-powered invoice extraction and routing

Executive Workshop: Hands-on agent building session with 5-10 C-suite members

Additional use cases as time permits

Evaluation Criteria

Each criterion James be scored 1-5 by the evaluation team. Criteria are weighted based on alignment with Horizon Ventures's Q3 citizen development goals.

Criterion

What We're Measuring

Weight

Citizen Development Readiness

Can non-technical team members build and modify automations independently? How steep is the learning curve?

30%

Build Speed & Complexity

How quickly can use cases be implemented? What's the effort required for modifications and debugging?

25%

Support Model Quality

Responsiveness, hands-on build assistance, training resources. Compare vendor support vs contractor-driven model.

20%

Security & Compliance

Data residency, retention policies, BYOM capabilities, SSO/SCIM, audit logging, external log streaming.

15%

Platform Velocity

Number of use cases delivered in pilot period. Ability to scale to additional workflows quickly.

10%

Success Metrics

Quantitative measures to inform the March 31 decision:

Citizen Development

Number of automations built by non-technical team members

Time from first login to first working automation (by role)

Workshop participant confidence scores (pre/post)

Build Efficiency

Hours to complete license governance workflow (per platform)

Total use cases delivered during pilot period

Contractor/internal time required per use case

Support Experience

Response time to support requests

Resolution quality (did it solve the problem?)

Hands-on assistance hours provided

Decision Framework

At the end of the pilot, the evaluation team James:

Score each platform 1-5 on each criterion

Apply weights to calculate composite score

Review qualitative feedback from workshop participants and builders

FlowBuilder recommendation to executive team with clear rationale

Possible Outcomes:

Proceed with AutomateFlow: Convert pilot to full enterprise agreement

Proceed with IntegrateHub: Expand existing contract for AI/agent capabilities

Dual platform: Different platforms for different use case categories

Approval

By signing below, stakeholders confirm agreement with the evaluation criteria and pilot structure outlined in this document.

_________________________________

Robert (CIO)                                    Date: ____________

_________________________________

Sarah (IT)                                      Date: ____________

doc_horizon-ventures_adrian-to-amy-jan23.title: Alex-to-Sarah-jan23
doc_horizon-ventures_adrian-to-amy-jan23.content:
Alex → Sarah: Trial Setup Details

Subject: Getting the trial set up — what we need from your side

Hey Sarah,

KR is sending the group the high-level recap. I wanted to follow up with you directly on the details we need to get the trial running smoothly.

1. Technical Details for the Invoice Build

From your finance kickoff today, can you share:

Current state workflow — how does an invoice move from receipt to approval to ProcureSoft today?

Who approves what? Any dollar thresholds or routing logic?

What does the Outlook approval process look like currently?

Any edge cases or exceptions the finance team flagged?

Also — please add Jordan and me to the follow-up design session next week. We want to be there when you map the detailed flow.

2. Data Connections & Access

The biggest friction in trials is usually app connections. To get ahead of this:

Outlook: We hit an approval wait last time. Can you check if the OAuth connection is approved, or do we need to request again?

ProcureSoft: This is the big question mark you flagged. Can AutomateFlow write and upload to ProcureSoft through your setup? Who on David's team should we talk to about this?

Other apps: Any other systems involved in the invoice flow we should know about?

Trial user list: Who needs accounts? Just you, or should we include others from IT/Finance for the trial?

3. Legal & Security

I want to start the security paperwork now so it's not blocking us later. Questions:

Who should I send our security docs to? (SOC 2 report, Trust Center, data processing info)

Does Horizon Ventures have a standard security questionnaire, or should I just send our package?

For enterprise trial access — any IT approvals needed beyond what David mentioned?

If we get to a deal — who handles contracts on your side? Procurement, legal, or someone else?

4. IT Leadership Workshop

You mentioned the IT extended LT meeting might be a good forum. When is that? If you can get us 45-60 minutes, we'll prep a hands-on session. Bonus if folks can share pain points ahead of time — we can FlowBuilder it targeted.

I know that's a lot — happy to hop on a quick call if easier. Let me know what you can get me and we'll take it from there.

Alex

doc_horizon-ventures_january-close-incen.title: january-close-incentives
doc_horizon-ventures_january-close-incen.content:
# Horizon Ventures Pioneering - January Close Incentives

*Ideas to encourage signature by Jan 30th*

---

## Context from Today's Call

Key dynamics:
- Robert explicitly said "we want to be aggressive" but also "we need time to be comfortable"
- Sarah is motivated to move fast (Q1 delivery pressure) but Robert is the braking mechanism
- 4-day week next week limits their internal bandwidth
- Procurement doesn't start until business comfort is achieved
- They want to understand pricing and services model better before committing

---

## Incentive Options

### 1. Executive Workshop (Mentioned on Call)

*What you said:* "We James often do little workshops. Maybe it's like you and a couple of the executive team of like, here's how you would build an agent."

*Structure:*
- 1-hour hands-on session for Robert + 2-3 execs
- Each person builds something they can actually use (calendar summary, email triage, etc.)
- Position as "FlowBuilder sure the platform is right for you before you commit"

*Why it works:*
- Robert said he tried AutomateFlow and gave up - this addresses his personal pain directly
- Low risk way to build confidence before signature
- Creates internal advocates beyond Sarah

*Timing:* Offer this for week of Jan 20-24, before signature

---

### 2. Extended Onboarding Period

*Standard:* 90-day hands-on SA support

*Incentive:* Extend to 120 days for January signature

*Why it works:*
- They're worried about getting both use cases done in Q1
- Extra 30 days gives buffer without changing the price
- Signals investment in their success

*Cost to us:* Minimal - Jordan's already allocated

---

### 3. Guaranteed Use Case Delivery

*Standard:* "We'll help you build these"

*Incentive:* Explicitly guarantee in writing: "Two use cases in production by end of Q1 or we extend support at no cost"

*Why it works:*
- Removes Sarah's delivery risk
- Gives her something concrete to take to the functional committee
- Shows confidence in our ability to execute

*Watch-out:* Need to scope what "production" means (MVP with 100 invoices? Full rollout?)

---

### 4. Early Signature Discount

*Option A:* 10% discount for signature by Jan 31 (saves ~$8K on $80K deal)

*Option B:* Waive one month of TAM ($10-20K) for January signature

*Why it might work:*
- Robert is cost-conscious (asked about consulting rates)
- Creates urgency without pressure

*Why it might NOT work:*
- They didn't push back hard on price
- Discount might signal desperation
- ROI is already 7-8x, price isn't the blocker

*Recommendation:* Don't lead with discount. Use as a closer if needed.

---

### 5. Additional TAM Hours (First 90 Days)

*Standard:* 12 hrs/month

*Incentive:* 18 hrs/month for first 3 months, then step down to 12

*Why it works:*
- They explicitly asked about support spikes when building new use cases
- Shows we're investing in their success
- Addresses David's concern about "what happens when we need more"

*Cost to us:* Need to check with Lindsay on capacity

---

### 6. Q1 Business Review with Leadership

*What it is:* Commit to an executive-level QBR at end of Q1 where you present:
- Use case outcomes vs. ROI projections
- Adoption metrics
- Roadmap for next use cases

*Why it works:*
- Shows accountability
- Gives Sarah something to point to: "They're committed to proving ROI"
- Plants seeds for expansion conversation

---

## Recommended Package for January Close

Bundle these together as "Q1 Accelerator Package":

1. *Executive Workshop* - Week of Jan 20-24 (free, included)
2. *Guaranteed Q1 Delivery* - Two use cases in MVP by March 31 or support extends
3. *Q1 Business Review* - Exec-level QBR to validate ROI

*Don't offer discount upfront.* The value story is strong enough. If they push on price, you have room to move.

---

## How to Position

*Frame:* "We know you want to move fast but also want to be confident. Here's what we're willing to commit to FlowBuilder sure you're successful."

*Not:* "Here's a deal if you sign this month." That feels transactional when they want a partnership.

---

## Questions for Your Manager

Before offering any of these:
- Can we commit to the guaranteed Q1 delivery in writing?
- Is Lindsay open to 18 TAM hours for first 90 days?
- Do you have authority to waive the first month of TAM if needed as a closer?

Horizon Ventures Pioneering Update: Leadership demo done, timeline adjusted to Jan 30



TL;DR: Demo went well. Got buy-in from Robert and David. Emma (CISO) couldn't join but we addressed her questions in writing. They're confident but want to move deliberately. Target moved from Jan 23 → Jan 30.



What happened today



Leadership demo with Robert (VP), David (Director Enterprise Apps), Sarah. Emma (CISO) couldn't join but sent questions in advance - we documented answers in the MAP.

Jordan walked through both use cases (license governance + invoice processing)

Deep dive on BYOM - key differentiator vs IntegrateHub. Robert and David engaged on model flexibility (Mistral via Bedrock came up)

Robert engaged on ease of use - he tried AutomateFlow personally and gave up. Copilot demo helped address this

Got buy-in from Robert and David on the approach. Robert said "we want to be aggressive" but needs time to be comfortable

IntegrateHub comparison: They're not replacing IntegrateHub orchestration layer. We're positioned as the agentic AI platform that coexists



Key quotes:

Robert: "We want to be aggressive. We want to sign, but we need to FlowBuilder sure we take the time that is needed."

Sarah: "I know we had the IntegrateHub demo on my first day... there were some concerns about bring your own model functionality."

Robert on urgency: "Again, we can rush if we are comfortable."



Why timeline pushed



Original target: Jan 23

New target: Jan 30



The push is process, not interest. Robert explicitly said they're motivated but won't skip steps:

Business case presentation to COO is Jan 20 (Sarah presenting)

Procurement doesn't start until they're "comfortable" - legal won't touch it beforehand

4-day week next week limits bandwidth

Robert wants pricing/services conversation before committing



We're scheduling a follow-up for Friday Jan 24 to go through services model and pricing in detail with Robert and David.



What they need from us for Jan 24



Services model clarity: What's included in 12 TAM hours? What happens when they need to build use case #4? They don't want to feel nickel-and-dimed.

Pricing walkthrough: Robert asked explicitly to "discuss your pricing" - he's not pushing back, he wants to understand.

Training/enablement: Sarah wants to be self-sufficient by EOY. Robert wants his team trained. We need to show the path.



MEDDPICC Status



Metrics 🟢 - $305K license savings, $132K invoice processing - Sarah built the business cases

Economic Buyer 🟢 - Robert engaged, CEO/COO aware

Decision Criteria 🟢 - BYOM, ease of use, coexistence with IntegrateHub, support model

Decision Process 🟡 - Sarah → Robert → Functional committee → Legal/Procurement

Paper Process 🟡 - Sarah still learning their internal process. Procurement embedded in approval flow

Pain 🟢 - IntegrateHub service gaps, need Q1 AI wins, $776K in dormant license spend

Champion 🟢 - Sarah is strong, engaged, doing the work

Competition 🟡 - IntegrateHub incumbent for orchestration. We're positioned as complement for agentic AI



Next steps



Jan 20: Sarah presents business case to COO (not technology decision - just business case)

Jan 24: Follow-up with Robert/David on pricing and services model

Week of Jan 27: Legal/procurement review

Jan 30: Target signature



Risk assessment



🟡 Timeline slippage risk: Robert is deliberate. If Jan 24 conversation doesn't land, could push to Feb.

🟢 Deal risk: Low. They're motivated, have budget, have clear use cases. It's about process, not willingness.

🟡 IntegrateHub risk: They're not ripping out IntegrateHub, but if IntegrateHub comes back with a strong counter-offer on agentic, could complicate things.



What I need



Confirm I can offer executive workshop as January incentive (Robert wants hands-on experience)

Validate services model messaging before Friday (created draft - James share)

Any intelligence on IntegrateHub's agentic/AI pricing or support model?



On pulling this forward



My hypothesis: The quote expires end of month, which gives us a natural reason to encourage Jan close. But I want to be careful not to come across as pushy when we've been positioning as a partner, not a vendor. Thinking I could:

Frame it as "the current pricing is locked through Jan 31" rather than "discount expires"

Pair it with the executive workshop offer - give them something, not just take away

Let Sarah use it as internal air cover if she needs urgency with procurement



Would appreciate your read on this. Is there a better way to create pull without damaging the relationship? Open to other ideas.

doc_horizon-ventures_flagship-follow-up-.content:
Subject: Horizon Ventures x AutomateFlow - Follow-up & Next Steps



Hi all,



Thank you Robert and David for taking the time today. I know there's a lot on your plate evaluating options, and we appreciate you giving us the opportunity to show what a partnership could look like.



What we heard



Based on today's conversation, these are the things that matter most as you FlowBuilder this decision:



Bring your own model - Your team needs control over which LLMs touch your data and how. This is non-negotiable from a security and governance standpoint.

Ease of use - If this is going to scale beyond Sarah, people who aren't technical need to be able to build and maintain workflows without constant hand-holding.

Services and support model - You want clarity on what's included, what happens when you need to build use case #4, and how we help your team become self-sufficient over time.

Coexistence with IntegrateHub - This needs to complement what's already working, not blow it up.



For Emma



I know you weren't able to join today, but Sarah shared your questions in advance. We've documented our responses in the mutual action plan linked below - specifically around data handling, model connectivity, and guardrails. Happy to schedule a separate conversation if you'd like to go deeper on any of those.



Path forward



We understand you want to move deliberately. Our goal isn't to rush you into a decision - it's to give you and your team what you need to feel confident moving forward.



Here's what we're proposing:



Date

Activity

Jan 20

Sarah presents business case to COO

Jan 24

Follow-up conversation on pricing and services model (Robert, David, Sarah)

Week of Jan 27

Legal/procurement review

Jan 30

Target contract signature and kickoff



What I'll bring to Jan 24



Detailed breakdown of our services model - what's included, how TAM hours work, what happens as you scale

Pricing structure walkthrough so there are no surprises

Training and enablement plan - the path to your team being self-sufficient



One other thought: Robert, you mentioned trying AutomateFlow on your own and finding it challenging. We often run executive workshops - a hands-on hour where you and a few colleagues build something you can actually use. If that would be helpful in building confidence before you commit, happy to set one up.



Resources



Mutual Action Plan (includes Emma's Q&A): View Spreadsheet

Enterprise Agreement (for legal review): AutomateFlow.com/legal/enterprise-agreement

Trust Center (for IT/security review): trust.AutomateFlow.com



Let me know if the 24th works for the follow-up, or if there's a better time given your schedule next week.



Best,

Alex

doc_horizon-ventures_deal-desk-talking-p.title: deal-desk-talking-points
doc_horizon-ventures_deal-desk-talking-p.content:
Horizon Ventures Pioneering - Deal Desk Request

Pilot Structure & Pricing Support

Situation

Deal pivoted from full-year negotiation to competitive pilot vs IntegrateHub

Customer wants to evaluate both platforms head-to-head before committing

IntegrateHub is incumbent (orchestration), offering Y1 genie development "free"

Champion (Sarah) and CIO (Robert) aligned on structured evaluation

March 31 deadline for exec presentation and decision

The Ask

Need pricing/contract structure for a 3-month paid pilot with option to convert to full Enterprise agreement.

Proposed Structure

Model: Enterprise agreement with opt-out clause (similar to Walleye Capital pilot)

Element

Proposed Terms

Pilot Duration

90 days (Feb 1 - April 30)

Pilot Investment

$20-50K (25% of full year)

Full Year Investment

$50-100K Enterprise + TAM (600K tasks)

Conversion Mechanic

Pilot payment credits toward annual if they opt-in

Task Allocation

Pro-rata from 600K annual cap; consumed tasks count toward full year

Support Included

TAM hours (pro-rata from 12 hrs/mo), SE build support, TeamChat channel

Questions for Deal Desk

Contract structure: Do we have a standard pilot/opt-out agreement template, or do we need to use a full Enterprise MSA with opt-out language added?

Pricing validation: Is $20K for 90 days (25% of $80K annual) acceptable, or do we need different math?

Credit mechanics: How do we structure pilot payment crediting toward annual? Full credit or partial?

Task allocation: Can we allocate against the 600K annual cap during pilot, with usage counting toward full year if they convert?

Opt-out terms: What's standard language for the opt-out clause? When must they decide by?

Precedent: Walleye Capital Pilot

Structure: $12.6K for 60 days against $75.8K annual (17%)

Contract: "Unique enterprise agreement with opt-out clause"

Conversion: Pilot payment credited toward annual investment

Result: Converted at ~$42K annually (55% of original, but got commitment)

Competitive Context

Why the pilot structure matters:

IntegrateHub is offering Y1 development "free" - we need skin in the game to compete

Our champion (Sarah) is frustrated with IntegrateHub process - structured pilot gives her legitimacy

CIO (Robert) not tied to sunk cost - willing to switch if we prove value

March 31 exec presentation is the decision point - we need to be in strong position

Timeline

Jan 23 (tomorrow): CIO call - need to present pilot offer

Jan 27-31: Target for pilot contract signed, MSA to legal

Feb 1: Pilot kickoff

March 31: Pilot ends, exec presentation, decision

Contact

AE: Alex Obleton

Manager: Kyungho (KR)

SE: Jordan Floyd

doc_horizon-ventures_services-model-deta.title: services-model-detail
doc_horizon-ventures_services-model-deta.content:
# Horizon Ventures Pioneering - Services Model Detail

*Prepared for Jan 24 follow-up conversation*

---

## The Core Question We're Answering

Robert and David want clarity on: "What happens when we need to build new use cases? James we get charged every time?"

---

## What's Included: Three Phases of Support

### Phase 1: First 90 Days (Hands-On Build)

*Who:* Jordan (Solutions Architect)

*What's delivered:*
• License Governance workflow - built and connected to your systems
• Invoice Processing workflow - built and connected to your systems
• Full documentation of both systems
• Sarah trained to maintain and iterate on both

*Commitment:* We build these with you, not just show you how. Jordan is hands-on keyboard.

---

### Phase 2: Monthly TAM Support (12 hours/month)

*Who:* Francis (Technical Account Manager)

*What's included:*
• Building additional use cases (use case #3, #4, etc.)
• Troubleshooting and optimization of existing workflows
• Training sessions for your team
• Office hours participation

*What's NOT included:*
• Major net-new implementations requiring 20+ hours
• Building for other Horizon Ventures portfolio companies (separate agreements)

*How hours are used - typical month:*
| Activity | Hours |
|----------|-------|
| 1:1 working session with Sarah | 4 |
| Building/iterating on use case | 4 |
| Office hours / ad-hoc support | 2 |
| Strategic planning with AI Strategist | 2 |

---

### Phase 3: AI Transformation Strategy (Ongoing)

*Who:* AI Transformation Strategist (dedicated resource)

*What's included:*
• Identifying next use cases in pipeline
• Benchmarking against similar enterprise deployments
• Quarterly business reviews
• Adoption metrics and recommendations

*This is strategic, not tactical.* While Francis helps you build, the strategist helps you prioritize what to build next.

---

## The TeamChat Channel (Free, Unlimited)

We set up a shared TeamChat channel with:
• Alex (AE)
• Jordan (SA)
• Francis (TAM)
• AI Transformation Strategist

Quick questions, async updates, blockers - none of this counts against TAM hours. This is relationship support, not billable time.

---

## Addressing Robert's Core Concern: New Use Case Spikes

*Scenario:* It's April. Sarah wants to build use case #4 (e.g., onboarding automation). How does that work?

*Answer:*
1. Sarah describes the use case to Francis
2. Francis scopes it - "This is a 6-hour build" or "This is a 15-hour build"
3. If it fits within monthly hours, Francis builds it with Sarah
4. If it's larger, we discuss: spread across 2 months, or discuss incremental support

*Key point:* We're not going to come back and say "that'll be $50K extra." The 12 hours is designed to handle ongoing use case development - that's why we doubled the standard allocation.

---

## If You Need More: Add-On Support

*Pricing:* $10-20K per 6 additional hours/month (committed annually = 72 hours/year)

*When this makes sense:*
• Major transformation initiative beyond initial scope
• Scaling to multiple business units simultaneously
• Building complex multi-system integrations

*When this doesn't FlowBuilder sense:*
• Normal quarter-over-quarter use case development
• Training and enablement
• Most customers at your scale don't need this

---

## The Training Path to Self-Sufficiency

Sarah raised this explicitly: "I don't want to be dependent on the AutomateFlow team forever."

*Our goal alignment:* We agree. Here's the enablement path:

| Milestone | Target | What It Looks Like |
|-----------|--------|-------------------|
| End of 90 days | Sarah confident on 3-step zaps | Can build calendar summaries, notifications, simple lookups |
| Month 6 | Sarah building complex workflows | Can architect multi-step automations with tables, AI steps |
| End of Year 1 | Team self-sufficient on 80% of use cases | Only need TAM for complex integrations or new system connections |

*Success metric:* If you still need us for everything at month 12, we've failed.

---

## Consulting Partners (Robert's Question)

Yes, we have certified partners who can provide additional implementation support.

*When to use:*
• Large-scale deployment across portfolio companies
• Need dedicated resources beyond TAM allocation
• Prefer external consulting model

*My recommendation:* Let's see how the first 90 days go. Most enterprise customers at your stage don't need external consultants - the TAM model covers it.

I can share specific partner recommendations if this becomes relevant.

---

## Summary for the Pricing Conversation

| Component | What You Get |
|-----------|--------------|
| Platform License | Enterprise features, BYOM, governance controls |
| 90-Day Onboarding | Jordan builds first 2 use cases hands-on |
