messages.text:
Horizon Ventures Pioneering Update: Leadership demo done, timeline adjusted to Jan 30

TL;DR: Demo went well. Got buy-in from Robert and David. Emma (CISO) couldn't join but we addressed her questions in writing. They're confident but want to move deliberately. Target moved from Jan 23 → Jan 30.

What happened today

• Leadership demo with Robert (VP), David (Director Enterprise Apps), Sarah. Emma (CISO) couldn't join but sent questions in advance
• Jordan walked through both use cases
• Deep dive on BYOM - key differentiator vs IntegrateHub
• Got buy-in from Robert and David
• Robert said "we want to be aggressive" but needs time

MEDDPICC Status
• Metrics: $305K license savings, $132K invoice processing
• Economic Buyer: Robert engaged, CEO/COO aware
• Champion: Sarah is strong
• Competition: IntegrateHub incumbent

messages.author: Alex.obleton
messages.text:
Horizon Ventures Pioneering - Services Model for Jan 24

For: @user @user @user @user

From: Alex

Date: Jan 16, 2026

Context: I have a pricing and services call with Horizon Ventures on Jan 24 where I'll walk through our support model in detail. We already have approval for 12 TAM hours/month (thanks Linds) - this note is about how I'm positioning the way those hours get used. Want to FlowBuilder sure we're aligned before I go deeper with the customer.

Deal Snapshot
• Account: Horizon Ventures Pioneering (~$80K, targeting Jan 30 close)
• Champion: Sarah - driving internally, wants to be self-sufficient by EOY
• Economic buyer: Robert (VP) - engaged, said "we want to be aggressive, we want to sign"
• Use cases: License governance ($305K savings) and invoice processing ($132K savings)

The Model I'm Selling

Here's how I'm positioning our support model to Horizon Ventures:

First 90 Days (Jordan - SA)
• Hands-on build of first 2 use cases (license governance + invoice processing)
• Full documentation of both systems
• Sarah trained to maintain and iterate on both

Monthly TAM - 12 hrs/month (Francis)
• Hands-on keyboard for additional use cases (use case #3, #4, etc.)
• Training sessions to get Sarah building confidently
• Office hours and troubleshooting support

AI Automation Strategist (CSM)
• Coordinates across our team and theirs
• Use case roadmap and prioritization
• Adoption metrics and QBRs

The pitch is that this is a partnership model, not a vendor relationship. We're not just giving them software and a support number - we're actively helping them build and scale their AI automation program.

groundTruth.whatHappenedNext: **Trial check-in - pivoting to paid pilot.** Key outcomes: (1) **Evaluation criteria locked:** Citizen dev usability (40%), central IT build capability (40%), security/compliance (table stakes), platform velocity. Sarah James fill out eval, Robert decides based on her confidence. (2) **Timeline confirmed: End of March.** Sarah going back to COO + functional leadership then - no Feb close possible. (3) **Pilot pricing anchored at $20K for 2 months** (1.5x prorated) - includes Jordan's dedicated time. KR aligned on this approach. (4) **Technical win: ProcureSoft API now working.** OAuth resolved (needed newline-separated scopes), successfully retrieving PO data, invoice workflow nearly end-to-end. (5) **New use case: BrandFolder facial recognition** - batch photo tagging with Google Vision API. Good 2-month pilot project. (6) **Next steps:** Sarah pitches Robert in 1:1 tomorrow, Emma reviews security/legal, Jordan demos full flow to Lisa tomorrow. If Robert verbal yes → formal quote → contract execution.. **Working session with Sarah, David, Mike (IntegrateHub SME).** Key progress: (1) Crawl/walk/run approach agreed for invoice automation - start with recurring invoices, add human-in-loop, then automate high-confidence matches. (2) AutomateFlow Form + Table set up for PDF testing - bypasses Outlook blocker. (3) Sarah has ProcureSoft admin access, Jordan sent API endpoint requirements (invoices, POs, images). (4) 15 users added to trial including David (admin) and Mike. (5) Mike met Jordan for first time - has IntegrateHub experience, used AutomateFlow ~2 years ago. **Blockers:** Outlook OAuth still no timeline, ProcureSoft API not yet connected. **Other opportunities:** Sarah experimenting with Brandfolder MCP + facial recognition (Google Vision API), asked about MCP pricing (Jordan to follow up). **Workshop:** Rachel Mabie confirmed for Feb 18. Need to get exec Outlook accounts approved before workshop. **Action:** Ask Sarah to amend Outlook request to include leadership team.. (Evening)**: **Security email + memo sent to Emma.** Short email with links + detailed memo uploaded to Google Doc. Offered call if needed. Next: follow up if no response.. (Evening)**: **Workshop planning started.** Feb 18 workshop needs prep: (1) All connections set up beforehand (Outlook OAuth, ProcureSoft), (2) Consider Rachel Mabie for "build your own agent" format, (3) Get attendee pain points in advance. Jordan + Sarah to work Monday on connections and trial user list.. (Evening)**: **Sarah responded with key details:** **IT Workshop: Feb 18 at 9:30am ET** - Robert approved, Sarah adding us to agenda **EA = Enterprise Applications** (David's team), not Executive Assistants - kills the quick win angle **ProcureSoft**: Sarah requesting admin access. Question on whether constraints are admin setup or API - she thought API but checking **Outlook OAuth**: Not approved by security yet, Sarah pinged and following up **Security/Legal**: Emma Starr (InfoSec) + Legal handles contracts. "Send package" approach works **Trial users**: Sarah James compile list, should include others beyond just her **Finance design session**: Team said review flowchart together once built **Created security brief for Emma** - SOC 2, GDPR, BYOM, enterprise controls, links to Trust Center/Enterprise Agreement. Output: `/outputs/security-brief-Emma.docx`. (Late PM)**: KR sent follow-up email to Robert, David, Sarah, Emma confirming trial structure. Outlined: (1) Two-week enterprise trial with full support from Jordan, (2) Invoice automation build continues with Sarah + Jordan, (3) IT Leadership Workshop for hands-on citizen dev testing, (4) Jan 29 check-in to assess progress and decide next steps. Framed as "define value together" and "lower your team's risk with a paid pilot." **Sarah and David accepted the Jan 29 meeting.** I'm following up with Sarah on tactical details.. (PM)**: KR debrief. Feedback: Should have asked "paid vs non-paid pilot" earlier to shortcut discussion. Risk flagged: Customer using "agents/agentic" without understanding - we don't price agents. Opportunity: EA use case on IntegrateHub may be expensive recipe we can replace quickly. Action items: Start security paperwork, clarify EA use case, prepare for Jan 29 with clear "if they want more time, they put money down" positioning. Different views on call approach - KR thinks trial is cleaner than pilot, I'm concerned Robert James just ask for more time regardless.. Alignment call with Robert, David, Sarah, Emma. Robert and Emma had 9am conflict, left after 30 min. **Key outcome: Pivoted from 3-month paid pilot to 2-week enterprise trial.** Robert firm: "Won't pay before we prove ourselves." KR pushed back on pilot approach - citizen development gets delayed, full connections still needed anyway. Landed on: (1) Enterprise trial with Jordan support continuing, (2) Thursday Jan 29 check-in, (3) Sarah/Jordan continue invoice automation build, (4) IT leadership workshop in next couple weeks, (5) Brian + David join technical builds for comparison. **$80K confirmed in range if we prove value.** Evaluation criteria rubric not validated. David was candid: "IntegrateHub is known, we're giving AutomateFlow a fair shot." Biggest technical question mark: ProcureSoft integration.
actualRisksThatMaterialized: **Working session with Sarah, David, Mike (IntegrateHub SME).** Key progress: (1) Crawl/walk/run approach agreed for invoice automation - start with recurring invoices, add human-in-loop, then automate high-confidence matches. (2) AutomateFlow Form + Table set up for PDF testing - bypasses Outlook blocker. (3) Sarah has ProcureSoft admin access, Jordan sent API endpoint requirements (invoices, POs, images). (4) 15 users added to trial including David (admin) and Mike. (5) Mike met Jordan for first time - has IntegrateHub experience, used AutomateFlow ~2 years ago. **Blockers:** Outlook OAuth still no timeline, ProcureSoft API not yet connected. **Other opportunities:** Sarah experimenting with Brandfolder MCP + facial recognition (Google Vision API), asked about MCP pricing (Jordan to follow up). **Workshop:** Rachel Mabie confirmed for Feb 18. Outlined: (1) Two-week enterprise trial with full support from Jordan, (2) Invoice automation build continues with Sarah + Jordan, (3) IT Leadership Workshop for hands-on citizen dev testing, (4) Jan 29 check-in to assess progress and decide next steps. Quote ready from deal desk - James send DocuSign immediately on verbal yes. **Lisa demo completed - strong reception.** Key outcomes: (1) Lisa (AP lead, 8 yrs at Horizon Ventures, oversees 52-54 portfolio companies) now engaged and impressed - "completely eye-opening." (2) Major pain point validated: Thermo Fisher Financial = 100-150 invoices/month, same contract amounts, currently manual copy/paste. Non-PO invoices always go to same GL - prime candidate for end-to-end automation. (3) Technical decisions: Use "New" status (not Draft - Draft queue is a nightmare), leave PO matching unmatched unless 100% confident, test in ProcureSoft sandbox (David to coordinate access). (4) New automation opportunity: Draft cleanup bot - clear drafts with "none" values after 30 days (Alex idea, Lisa loved it). (5) Lisa + Kevin want to join Feb 18 workshop. (6) Rossum comparison meeting in a couple weeks - but Lisa said AutomateFlow "seems simpler and gives more control.". Initial discovery. Identified license governance and invoice processing as priority use cases.

tasks.prompt: Analyze the current state of this deal. Identify key risks, recommend next steps, and assess the likelihood of closing. Consider all available information.
Summarize this call. Identify key commitments made, objections raised, and action items. Assess the stakeholder sentiment.
Draft a follow-up email based on the recent interactions. The email should advance the deal, address any concerns raised, and include clear next steps.
Map the key stakeholders in this deal. For each, identify their role in the decision process, sentiment, concerns, and level of influence. Identify any missing stakeholders that should be engaged.
